item.title: A Comprehensive Comparison of Basic Education in Spain: The Truth Chinese Parents Should Know
item.description:
Spain has a free and compulsory education system for ages 6 to 16, covering 6 years of primary school and 4 years of middle school.

ğŸ“š School Hours and Tuition Differences

  • Spanish Public Schools: School hours are from 9:00â€“14:00, with 4 classes per day, and are free of charge.
  • Spanish Private and International Schools: School hours are typically from 9:00â€“16:00, with 6 classes per day.
    • The median tuition for private schools is approximately â‚¬6,000/year (about 50,000 RMB).
    • International schools cost around â‚¬8,000/year (about 70,000 RMB).
    • There are significant variations based on grade level, region, and school, with costs potentially differing by 1-2 times.

ğŸ« Teaching Staff and Pedagogical Features

  • Teacher absenteeism is relatively high in Spain. A doctor’s note for sick leave has legal force and can be issued over the phone for paid sick leave.
  • Primary schools generally use a “generalist” system, where a single teacher teaches multiple subjects like English, math, humanities, science, art, and physical education, limiting subject-specific expertise.
  • Subject-specific teaching only begins in middle school.
  • The saying “the gym teacher taught my math” is not a joke in Spain but a result of the generalist system in primary schools.
  • Exam scores are not ranked.

ğŸˆ¯ Language of Instruction and Multilingual Environment

  • International schools primarily use English for instruction;
  • Private and public schools mainly use Spanish;
  • Autonomous communities like Valencia and Catalonia require the study of local languages;
  • In middle school, a second foreign language such as French or German is added, making the multilingual workload heavy.

ğŸ“– Workload and Holiday Schedule

  • There is less homework after school.
  • The academic year is divided into three terms, with a total of about 160â€“180 teaching days.
  • Holidays are long.

ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡³ Comparison with Basic Education in China

  • Public Schools: School hours are from 8:00â€“16:00, with 6â€“8 classes per day, free of charge, with some regions offering after-school extension classes.
  • Private/International Schools: 8:00â€“17:30, with evening self-study sessions starting in middle school, which do not exist in Spain.
    • Private: Approximately 60,000 RMB/year
    • International: Approximately 180,000 RMB/year
  • The academic year is divided into two semesters, with more than 190 teaching days.

ğŸŸï¸ Disparity in Campus Facilities

  • International schools in China often have campuses of over 100 acres, featuring heated swimming pools, theaters, multimedia libraries, maker labs, Olympic-standard stadiums, and even equestrian fields, golf courses, and drone and robotics labs.
  • In contrast, Spanish schools are modest and compact, with simple facilities.

ğŸ“˜ Curriculum and Difficulty

Many people believe that primary school math in China is much more difficult than abroad, but this is a long-standing misconception.

item.title: A Summer Road Trip in Northern Spain: From Valencia to Covadonga
item.description: Last summer, I completed a 10-day grand road trip loop through northern Spain. Starting from Valencia, the route went through Zaragoza, Olite, Bilbao, Santander, Comillas, Covadonga, Salamanca, Avila, Madrid, and finally returned to Valencia after lunch in the cliff town of Cuenca. This journey offered a mix of cities, ancient castles, mountains, the sea, and delicious food. We were a group of four. This article shares all the details of the trip for anyone who might find it useful.

item.title: A Thousand-Year Soft-Shelled Turtle, a Ten-Thousand-Year Tortoise? How Much Longer Must We 'Take Things for Granted'?
item.description:
The old saying, “a soft-shelled turtle for a thousand years, a tortoise for ten thousand,” is one almost everyone has heard. In Chinese culture, turtles and tortoises are seen as symbols of longevity, as if they are naturally born to outlive several human generations.

But here’s the question: Are there really any ‘soft-shelled turtles’ that have lived for a thousand years?

Many people, upon seeing a massive tortoise or turtle, will blurt out, “Wow, this one must be hundreds of years old!” Such claims might “sound reasonable,” but in reality, they don’t stand up to the slightest scrutiny.

item.title: An Analysis of Local Incomes in Spain (Madrid vs. Beijing: Who Can Live a More Dignified Life?)
item.description:
My previous article, The Downsides of Living in Spain: A Detailed 2024 Comparison of Madrid vs. Beijing, objectively presented the cost of living in Spain with real and reliable data, yet it still sparked considerable debate. One commenter asked, “Why not compare the incomes of local Spaniards? Given their salaries, these prices are nothing.”

Alright, let’s complete the picture today: What are the income levels really like in Madrid and Beijing? We’ll cover high-income earners, blue-collar workers, and post-tax disposable income all in one go.

item.title: An Overview of European Ethnic Evolution: A Long-Term Process of Migration, Language Replacement, and Institutional Integration
item.description:
The ethnic structure of Europe is not fixed from ancient times but was gradually formed through a long historical process of prehistoric population migrations, language replacement, political conquests, and religious integration.

The following sections outline the main stages and structural characteristics of European ethnic evolution in chronological order.

I. Neolithic Era: Near Eastern Agricultural Populations Enter Europe

(c. 7000â€“5000 BC)

  • Source Near Eastern Fertile Crescent, Anatolia region

  • Paternal Genetic Signature Represented by haplogroup J (especially J2) (not exclusively, but a significant proportion in early agricultural diffusion)

item.title: The Downsides of Living in Spain: A Detailed 2024 Comparison of Madrid vs. Beijing
item.description: Spain has historically been regarded as a country with a high quality of life in Europe, attracting a large number of immigrants and international students. However, when we conduct a side-by-side comparison with China, particularly its capital Beijing, we find that Spain has significant shortcomings in many core aspects of life. item.title: The Ethnic Nature of the Han People: The 5,000-Year Inheritance of Huaxia Bloodline and Chinese Culture
item.description:
I. Mythological Beginnings: Yan, Huang, and Chiyou

The Records of the Grand Historian and Discourses of the States record that:

  • The Yellow Emperor defeated the Yan Emperor at the Battle of Banquan, causing the Yan tribe to submit;
  • He then defeated Chiyou at the Battle of Zhuolu, ultimately achieving victory.

This is not merely a legend but a symbol of the integration of ancient tribes:

  • The Yellow Emperor’s group: An agricultural tribe from the Central Plains, with the surname Ji;
  • The Yan Emperor’s group: A tribe with the surname Jiang, related to the ancient Qiang people;
  • Chiyou’s group: The Jiuli (Nine Li) tribes, ancestors of the southern Miao-Man peoples.

Ultimately, the people of the Yan Emperor and Chiyou were incorporated into the Yellow Emperor’s tribe, forming the “Huaxia.”

item.title: The Pinnacle of Algorithms and the Source of Logic: When 'Nine Chapters on the Mathematical Art' Meets 'Elements'
item.description:
At the dawn of human civilization, two mathematical works emerged in almost the same era. Like two rivers flowing in different directions, they quietly shaped the entirely different intellectual traditions of the East and West.

One came from China, the other from ancient Greece.

They are:

  • China’s ‘Nine Chapters on the Mathematical Art’
  • Ancient Greece’s ‘Elements’ (a translated title for part of Euclid’s Elements)

To this day, our understanding of science, technology, and even artificial intelligence still carries the DNA of these two books.

item.title: Was Ancient China's Imperial Examination System Only About the Eight-Legged Essay? (The Earliest Exams Combined Arts and Sciences)
item.description:
Historical and archaeological clarification:

The imperial examination system was not just about the eight-legged essay; it originally combined both arts and sciences.

The foundation of Han civilization’s belief system is rationality and ethics, not theocracy.

While Europe was burning in the flames of faith, China had long revered science.

Many people think ancient imperial exams only tested the eight-legged essay, and scholars were all “bookworms.”

But the opposite is true. For a long time, the true imperial examination system was a “dual cultivation of arts and sciences.” Ancient China was not only a nation of poetry, literature, rites, and music but also a civilization that revered science and rationality.

item.title: Why Did Europe Move Towards Democracy? â€” The Republican Tradition, Not an Accidental Historical Choice
item.description:
When people talk about European democracy, they often focus on a specific revolution or a particular declaration, as if democracy were an institutional innovation that suddenly appeared one day in modern times.

But if we look back through history, we will find a more fundamental and often overlooked fact:

Europe did not suddenly learn republicanism; it had long lived with the political experience that “a republic could exist.”

In Europe, the republic was never a momentary flash of inspiration, but a continuous institutional tradition spanning over two thousand years.

item.description:
{
 "title": "Is Sending Your Child to Study in Europe or the US Really Better for Their Mental Health?",
 "body": "Many parents send their children to study in Europe or the US for a common reason:

> \"Education abroad is more relaxed, kids have less pressure, are less prone to depression, and it's better for their mental health.\"

It sounds reasonable: children in China have a lot of homework, intense competition, and frequent exams, while children abroad seem happier, getting out of school around 3 p.m. for sports, clubs, dances, and summer camps.

But is this really the case? I had an in-depth discussion with an AI using data, and the conclusion might upend your assumptions.

---

## 01 Starting with the Intuition that 'Stress = Mental Health Problems'

Initially, the AI's response was like most people's:

> \"The American education system is more relaxed and thus more beneficial for adolescent mental health.\"

Its reasoning was: Less stress â†’ Less anxiety â†’ Better mental health.

This sounds logical, but it's based on impressions and speculation, not supported by data.

So I pressed further: \"Can we compare using quantitative indicators, like depression rates or suicide rates?\"

---

## 02 Depression Rates: Significant Data Discrepancies

The AI found adolescent depression rates for both China and the US, revealing huge statistical discrepancies for China:

| Metric | China | USA |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **Diagnosed Depressive Disorder** | â‰ˆ **2%** (ages 6â€“16, national review, Child & Adolescent Psychiatry & Mental Health 2024) | â‰ˆ **19â€“20%** (ages 12â€“17, major depressive episode in the past year, NIMH / SAMHSA NSDUH 2021â€“2022) |
| **Symptom Screening (Blue Book)** | 14.8% (2022 edition), 24.6% (2020 edition) | â€“ |
| **Meta-analysis Summary** | â‰ˆ 26% (synthesis of 439 studies) | â€“ |
| **Large-sample CES-D Study** | 39.93% positive | â€“ |
| **PHQ-9 Positive in Past Two Weeks** | â€“ | 19.2% (CDC NHANES 2021â€“2023) |
| **Self-reported Sadness/Hopelessness on Campus** | â€“ | 42% (CDC YRBS 2021) |

Looking only at this data, it's easy to conclude that \"depression among Chinese adolescents is severe.\" However, depressive symptoms are heavily influenced by scale thresholds and cultural expression, so they cannot be the sole standard.

---

## 03 Suicide Rates: The Most Objective Indicator of Mental Health

To eliminate cultural and scale-related biases, I looked up adolescent suicide rates. The results were very clear:

| Country | Age Group | Year | Suicide Rate (per 100,000) | Source |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| China | 10â€“19 | 2021 | **2.83** | JAMA Pediatrics 2023 |
| USA | 10â€“24 | 2021 | **11.0** | CDC NCHS Data Brief 471 |

The suicide rate among American adolescents is 3-4 times that of China's. Even accounting for differences in statistical scope, the US rate is still significantly higher.


![](/images/wechat/95e9a1fd9820.png)


---

## 04 The AI Admitted Its 'Mistake'

When I presented this data to the AI, it frankly admitted:

> \"My previous conclusion was based more on assumptions from training data and common public opinionâ€”that 'high stress = poor mental health'â€”rather than being derived from hard data.\"

It also stated that in the future, it would **base its reasoning on objective data** to avoid preconceived judgments and be truly scientific, objective, and fair.

This conversation left a deep impression on me: many parents, teachers, and even experts often rely on intuition rather than evidence when discussing \"mental health.\" The facts and public opinion can be two different things.


![](/images/wechat/efafb2ab495f.png)


---

## 05 The Rebound During the Pandemic

It's worth noting that after hitting a low of **1.59/100,000** in 2017, China's adolescent suicide rate **rebounded to 2.83/100,000** in 2021.

This period coincided with the online learning phase of the COVID-19 pandemic. Many children were at home for online classes, lacking a classroom atmosphere, losing motivation to study, becoming addicted to online games and short videos, having their routines disrupted, and even experiencing increased conflict with family, leading to fluctuations in their mental state.

From this perspective, this rebound precisely illustrates thatâ€”

**Focused study and a regular routine are crucial factors in protecting adolescent mental health.**

When the rhythm of learning was disrupted and children were \"phoning it in\" by playing games on their computers, their mental health actually worsened.

---

## 06 Stress May Be Training for Psychological Resilience

The data tells us something unexpected:

> Academic pressure does not necessarily lead to mental breakdown; on the contrary, it may cultivate a child's ability to cope with stress.

Chinese children have to deal with exams, rankings, and comparisons from a young age, which teaches them emotional regulation and how to cope with setbacks earlier. In contrast, an overly relaxed environment may not help children deal with real-world pressures, potentially making them more fragile when they encounter genuine difficulties.

---

## 07 Takeaways for Parents

* **Don't panic at the mention of stress**: Moderate academic pressure can cultivate a sense of purpose and resilience.
* **Mental health is not just about 'having fun'**: A regular routine, engagement in studies, and family support are more critical.
* **Studying abroad is not a panacea**: Adolescent suicide rates are higher in Europe and the US, so studying abroad should not be seen as the sole solution to mental health problems.

---

## 08 Conclusion

Looking at the hard indicator of suicide rates, the mental health of Chinese adolescents is no worse than that of their American counterparts, and may even be better.

The rebound during the pandemic also reminds us:

> **Maintaining a regular study routine and focus is a key safeguard for mental health, not indulging in online games.**

And the AI's role in this discussion also offers a reminder:

> **Don't blindly follow 'public opinion and impressions'; use objective data to reason and arrive at more truthful conclusions.**"
}

 "title": "La cumbre de los algoritmos y el origen de la lÃ³gica: El encuentro entre *Los nueve capÃ­tulos sobre el arte matemÃ¡tico* y los *Elementos de Euclides*",
 "body": "En los albores de la civilizaciÃ³n humana, dos obras matemÃ¡ticas surgieron casi en la misma Ã©poca, pero como dos rÃ­os que fluyen en direcciones opuestas, moldearon silenciosamente **tradiciones de pensamiento completamente diferentes** en Oriente y Occidente.

Hasta el dÃ­a de hoy, nuestra forma de entender la **ciencia, la tecnologÃ­a e incluso la inteligencia artificial** sigue impregnada del ADN de estos dos libros.

***

## I. Contexto histÃ³rico: La verdad de los filÃ³sofos frente al manual de los administradores

En la historia de la ciencia occidental, la obra matemÃ¡tica mÃ¡s antigua y de mayor influencia posterior es los *Elementos* de Euclides (origen de lo que mÃ¡s tarde se conocerÃ­a como \"geometrÃ­a euclidiana\");
mientras que en la historia de la ciencia de la antigua China, el clÃ¡sico matemÃ¡tico mÃ¡s antiguo, mÃ¡s difundido y de mayor influencia es *Los nueve capÃ­tulos sobre el arte matemÃ¡tico*, compilado durante la dinastÃ­a Han.

Comparar estos dos \"clÃ¡sicos matemÃ¡ticos mÃ¡s importantes de sus respectivas civilizaciones\" no es para determinar un ganador, sino para comprender una cuestiÃ³n mÃ¡s prÃ¡ctica:

> **Â¿Por quÃ© dos sistemas matemÃ¡ticos antiguos de tan alto nivel**
> **terminaron contribuyendo a la ciencia natural moderna por caminos tan radicalmente distintos?**

***

### 1ï¸âƒ£ *Los Elementos*: MatemÃ¡ticas por amor a la \"verdad misma\"

* **Fecha de compilaciÃ³n**: Aprox. 300 a. C.
* **Autor**: Euclides
* **FunciÃ³n**: Una Â«escalera lÃ³gicaÂ» hacia las leyes del universo

A los *Elementos* no le interesaban las cosechas, los impuestos o los costes de ingenierÃ­a.

> **Â¿CÃ³mo debe definirse la matemÃ¡tica en sÃ­ misma?**

***

### 2ï¸âƒ£ *Los nueve capÃ­tulos sobre el arte matemÃ¡tico*: MatemÃ¡ticas al servicio del mundo real

***

## II. Diferencia en el punto de partida: Empezar por la \"definiciÃ³n\" frente a empezar por el \"problema\"

### ğŸ“ *Los Elementos*: Construir el universo desde la nada

El comienzo de Euclides no calcula Ã¡reas ni resuelve ecuaciones,

**Texto original:**

 *A point is that which has no part.*
* DefiniciÃ³n 2: **Una lÃ­nea es una longitud sin anchura.**

AquÃ­, Euclides no estÃ¡ calculando, sino haciendo **modelado abstracto**.

> **DefiniciÃ³n â†’ Axioma/Postulado â†’ ProposiciÃ³n â†’ DemostraciÃ³n**

**MÃ©todo (Algoritmo):**

Si Euclides tuviera que resolverlo:

### 3ï¸âƒ£ NÃºmeros positivos y negativos: El arte del rojo y el negro

{
 "title": "My Experience Passing the Spanish Driving Test",
 "body": "I passed my driving test, and I'm sharing my experience.

During the driving test in Spain, the examiner will only give instructions in Spanish, and the instructor is generally not allowed to translate. Therefore, it is crucial to master the following common commands and their Spanish expressions:

* **Start the engine**: Arrancar
* **Turn right**: Derecha
* **Turn left**: Izquierda
* **Go straight**: Recto
* **Make a U-turn**: Cambio de sentido
* **Indirect left turn**: izquierda indirecto
* **Roundabout**: Rotonda
* **First exit**: Primera salida
* **Second exit**: Segunda salida
* **Third exit**: Tercera salida
* **Fourth exit**: Cuarta salida
* **Stop**: Parar
* **Park**: Aparcar

If you don't hear an instruction clearly, you can ask the examiner to repeat it in Spanish, for example: â€œPor favor repitaâ€.

### **Pay Attention to Deviations in Examiner Instructions**

Sometimes the examiner might give an incorrect instruction, either intentionally or unintentionally. For example, if instructed to turn right, but there is a traffic sign at the intersection or on the road prohibiting a right turn, you should ignore the instruction and continue to follow the road signs.

At the same time, you should maintain a wide field of vision while driving and be aware that road markings are often about 30 meters before an intersection, while there may be no corresponding signs at the intersection itself. There are also vertical signs and traffic lights, with traffic lights having the highest priority. If there is a vertical STOP sign at an intersection but also a green light, you must strictly follow the higher-priority traffic light and not stop.

### **Understanding Roundabout Rules**

* **Urban roundabouts:**
 * For left turns and U-turns, you must use the inner lane.
 * When the inner lane has traffic lights, you can proceed directly on a green light. A flashing yellow light means you must yield to traffic from the right. Be sure to look to your right; you should yield to cars that are 25 meters away because they are moving fast.
 * For right turns and going straight, you should choose the outer lane.

* **Roundabouts outside the city:**
 * Always use the outer lane, unless you are overtaking, in which case you can use the inner lane.

When exiting a roundabout, be sure to signal right in advance and use your turn signal correctly to assist with lane changes. If traffic congestion prevents you from changing lanes to exit from the inner lane, you should continue to circle the roundabout until it is safe to change lanes, then switch to the rightmost lane (the further right, the better) to exit (in Spain, changing multiple lanes consecutively is permitted). For complex roundabouts divided into several islands, when making a circuitous left turn, enter from the rightmost lane. For going straight, you should choose the middle or leftmost lane. The keyword is *indirecto*.

### **Lane Selection and Intersection Driving**

* **When going straight:**
 * If there are three lanes, you should generally choose the first lane from the right;
 * If there are more than three lanes, it is recommended to use the second lane.

* **When passing through intersections:**
 * Avoid stopping on pedestrian crossings, bike lanes, or other special lanes, especially in congested areas marked with a yellow cross-hatch.
 * If the vehicle ahead stops due to lack of space, you should stop early and wait, ensuring your stopping position does not obstruct these special lanes.

### **Safe Driving and Right-of-Way Awareness**

Spanish traffic laws are very strict about right-of-way. People have a strong sense of right-of-way. At crosswalks without traffic lights, pedestrians have absolute priority. They are not in the habit of looking left and right for traffic and may cross suddenly. Therefore, when driving in areas where you do not have the right-of-way, you must remain highly alert, especially in sections with yield signs. You need to check for approaching traffic in bike lanes or vehicle lanes behind you and turn your head to confirm the situation.

However, when you have a green light, even if there are pedestrians on the crosswalk, you must not slow down or stop in advance, unless there is an unavoidable emergency, in which case only emergency braking is permitted. When approaching a crosswalk without traffic lights, you should slow down appropriately. If there are signs indicating students or children, you also need to perform a braking action to reduce speed.

Generally, the speed limit on urban roads is 50 km/h, while single-lane roads may be limited to 30 or 20 km/h. Roads outside the city are typically 90 km/h, and highways are 120 km/h. You are generally expected to drive as close to the maximum speed limit as possible; even exceeding it by 2-5 km/h is acceptable.

### **STOP Signs and Temporary Stopping Requirements**

When you encounter a STOP line on the road, you must stop before the line and wait for 3 seconds. Then, after moving about 1-2 meters past the line, you must stop again to observe the traffic conditions. This double stop is a test requirement. If visibility is poor, you should stop multiple times to ensure it is safe.

However, note that if there is also a traffic light, you must strictly follow the light's signal. You are not allowed to stop on a green light and must proceed directly; stopping in this case will result in a penalty. If there is no stop line, you should position your car about one meter into the intersection, stop for at least 3 seconds, confirm it is safe, and then proceed.

### **Driving Test Procedure and Strategy**

The driving test usually begins with 3-5 minutes of independent driving, after which the examiner will give instructions based on the situation. Since you may not be familiar with many of the routes on your first drive, it is advisable to observe distant road signs in advance. For example, entering a roundabout might require you to be in the left lane, while the right lane is for other directions; there are usually traffic signs above the intersection to indicate this. Sometimes, a left turn is not necessarily made from the left lane but may need to be completed from the right lane. In such cases, you must observe the road markings or overhead signs ahead of time and prepare to change lanes. If it's too late to change lanes, it is better to disobey the examiner's instruction than to force a lane change.

If road markings are difficult to see because they are blocked by a large vehicle or are faded, and there are no clear directional or prohibitive signs at the intersection, you can watch for hand signals from your instructor. When in doubt, it is advisable to choose to turn right and try to avoid turning left.


![](/images/wechat/b8469f50e5d2.jpg)


> The overhead road sign indicates entering the roundabout from the left lane.


![](/images/wechat/e13d835e1a4d.jpg)


> Prioritize the traffic light on the right; do not stop at a green light.


![](/images/wechat/35d3cf03f638.jpg)


> The road markings indicate a right turn only, but there is no sign at the intersection prohibiting a left turn. Therefore, if a large vehicle is blocking the view, it's difficult to recognize that a left turn is not allowed.


![](/images/wechat/d58308650bda.jpg)



![](/images/wechat/0148c0d9afcf.jpg)


> Two ways to navigate a roundabout"
}

 * Si el vehÃ­culo de delante se detiene por falta de espacio, debes detenerte antes y esperar, asegurÃ¡ndote de que tu posiciÃ³n no obstaculiza el uso de los carriles especiales.

### **ConducciÃ³n segura y conciencia de la prioridad de paso**

La normativa de trÃ¡fico en EspaÃ±a es muy estricta con la prioridad de paso. La gente tiene una fuerte conciencia de la prioridad. En los pasos de peatones no regulados por semÃ¡foros, los peatones tienen prioridad absoluta; no suelen tener la costumbre de mirar a ambos lados para ver el trÃ¡fico y pueden cruzar de repente. Por lo tanto, al conducir en zonas donde no se tiene prioridad, es fundamental mantenerse muy alerta, especialmente en tramos con seÃ±ales de ceda el paso, donde hay que observar si vienen vehÃ­culos por el carril bici o la calzada y girar la cabeza para confirmar la situaciÃ³n.

Sin embargo, con el semÃ¡foro en verde, aunque haya peatones en el paso, el conductor no debe reducir la velocidad ni detenerse con antelaciÃ³n, a menos que se encuentre ante una emergencia inevitable, en cuyo caso solo se permite una frenada de emergencia. Al pasar por un paso de peatones sin semÃ¡foro, se debe reducir la velocidad adecuadamente, y si hay seÃ±ales que advierten de la presencia de escolares o niÃ±os, es necesario realizar una acciÃ³n de frenado para reducir la velocidad.

En general, el lÃ­mite de velocidad en vÃ­as urbanas es de 50 km/h, aunque en tramos de carril Ãºnico puede estar limitado a 30 o 20 km/h. En carreteras fuera de poblado, generalmente es de 90 km/h, y en autopistas y autovÃ­as, de 120 km/h. Normalmente se exige circular lo mÃ¡s cerca posible del lÃ­mite mÃ¡ximo de velocidad, e incluso superar el lÃ­mite en 2-5 kilÃ³metros puede ser aceptable.

### **SeÃ±al de STOP y requisitos de detenciÃ³n**

Cuando te encuentres con una lÃ­nea de detenciÃ³n de un STOP, el conductor debe detenerse antes de la lÃ­nea y esperar 3 segundos, y despuÃ©s de sobrepasar la lÃ­nea aproximadamente 1-2 metros, detenerse de nuevo para observar el trÃ¡fico. Hacer 2 detenciones es un requisito del examen; si la visibilidad no es buena, se debe detener varias veces para confirmar la seguridad.

Pero atenciÃ³n: si al mismo tiempo hay un semÃ¡foro, se debe seguir estrictamente la indicaciÃ³n del semÃ¡foro. Con la luz verde no estÃ¡ permitido detenerse, hay que pasar directamente; detenerse en este caso es motivo de falta. Si no hay lÃ­nea de detenciÃ³n, se debe avanzar hasta que la parte delantera del vehÃ­culo sobresalga aproximadamente un metro en la intersecciÃ³n, detenerse al menos 3 segundos y, tras confirmar que es seguro, continuar la marcha.

### **Proceso del examen prÃ¡ctico y estrategia de conducciÃ³n**

El examen prÃ¡ctico suele comenzar con 3-5 minutos de conducciÃ³n autÃ³noma, tras los cuales el examinador darÃ¡ instrucciones segÃºn la situaciÃ³n. Como muchos tramos pueden no ser familiares la primera vez que se conduce por ellos, se recomienda observar con antelaciÃ³n las seÃ±ales lejanas. Por ejemplo, para entrar en una rotonda puede ser necesario hacerlo desde el carril izquierdo, mientras que el carril derecho es para otras direcciones; generalmente, sobre la intersecciÃ³n habrÃ¡ seÃ±ales que lo indiquen. A veces, para girar a la izquierda no es obligatorio ir por el carril izquierdo, sino que puede ser necesario hacer el giro desde el carril derecho. En estos casos, es necesario observar con antelaciÃ³n las marcas viales o las seÃ±ales elevadas para prepararse para el cambio de carril. Si ya es demasiado tarde para cambiar de carril, es preferible no seguir la instrucciÃ³n del examinador a forzar un cambio de carril.

Si las marcas viales de direcciÃ³n son difÃ­ciles de ver porque estÃ¡n tapadas por un vehÃ­culo grande o estÃ¡n borrosas, y en la intersecciÃ³n no hay seÃ±ales claras de direcciÃ³n o prohibiciÃ³n, se puede observar discretamente las indicaciones gestuales del profesor. En caso de duda, se recomienda girar a la derecha y evitar en lo posible girar a la izquierda.


![](/images/wechat/b8469f50e5d2.jpg)


> La seÃ±al superior indica que se debe entrar a la rotonda por el carril izquierdo.


![](/images/wechat/e13d835e1a4d.jpg)


> Prioridad al semÃ¡foro de la derecha; con luz verde, no hacer el stop.


![](/images/wechat/35d3cf03f638.jpg)


> Las marcas viales indican que solo se puede girar a la derecha, pero en la intersecciÃ³n no hay seÃ±al que prohÃ­ba girar a la izquierda, por lo que si un vehÃ­culo grande obstaculiza la visiÃ³n, es difÃ­cil saber que no se puede girar a la izquierda.

{
 "title": "Essential Apps for Blue-Line Street Parking in Spain & a Money-Saving Guide for Long-Term Airport Parking",
 "body": "In Spain, commercial parking lots are generally expensive. A few hours can easily cost tens of euros, which is a significant expense. To save money, consider using free roadside parking spots or the blue-line paid parking spaces provided by the municipality.

Blue-line parking spaces are cheaper, costing around â‚¬1 per hour, but manual payment is quite cumbersome. You need to go to a nearby payment machine, enter your license plate number and parking duration, and pay with coins or a card. If you leave early, the refund process is also quite troublesome. Therefore, it's highly recommended to use convenient parking payment apps for online payment and flexible billing, which is more economical and practical.

Additionally, taxi fares to Spanish airports are high. Traveling from a smaller city to Madrid's airport by train or bus can be troublesome and time-consuming. It would be much more convenient to park your own car near the airport and drive home directly upon your return. However, official airport parking is expensive, and long-term parking fees can be a major expense. So, how can you save money? In fact, there are specialized long-term parking lots near Spanish airports, with costs around â‚¬4 per day. This option is the most cost-effective for those traveling in groups.

## I. Essential Apps for Blue-Line Street Parking in Spain: Telpark & EasyPark

### Telpark: The Top Choice for Local Residents

Telpark is a widely used roadside parking payment app in Spain, covering blue-line parking spaces in most cities across the country and numerous public parking lots.

**Telpark's Key Features:**

* **Mobile Payment**: No cash needed; pay online anytime, anywhere.
* **Remote Renewal Reminders**: Receive automatic reminders before your parking expires, allowing you to extend your time and avoid fines.
* **Parking Location Log**: Automatically records your parking spot, making it easy to find your car.
* **Convenient Bill Management**: Check and download your parking bills at any time.

**Target Users**: Daily urban commuters.

Typically, municipal parking spaces have a maximum stay of 2 hours at a time. If you need to stay longer than 2 hours, you can end the current parking session in the app and immediately start a new one.


![](/images/wechat/25e1c194ea9b.jpg)



![](/images/wechat/f6c8463d69cf.jpg)


### EasyPark: A Must-Have for European Road Trips

EasyPark is ideal for users who frequently travel across European countries. It covers multiple European nations, making it especially suitable for cross-border road trips.

**EasyPark's Key Features:**

* **Multi-Country Coverage**: One app covers multiple European countries, saving you the hassle of downloading different applications.
* **Real-Time Parking Search**: Quickly find available parking spots nearby.
* **Flexible Billing Model**: Pay only for the actual time you are parked; start and stop sessions as you go.
* **Smart Reminders**: Avoid fines from overstaying your parking time.

**Target Users**: Users who frequently take road trips across European countries.

## II. Money-Saving Guide for Long-Term Airport Parking: Parkos

Parkos is a website that specializes in consolidating information from multiple long-term parking lots near airports, offering secure, convenient, and affordable parking solutions.

**Advantages of Parkos:**

* **Transparent and Competitive Pricing**: Compare prices from various parking lots near the airport to quickly choose the best option.
* **Variety of Services**: Includes indoor parking, outdoor parking, shuttle bus transfers, and valet parking services.
* **Convenient Online Booking**: Book online in advance to avoid waiting in line.
* **Guaranteed Parking Security**: Partner parking lots are rigorously vetted for safety and reliability.

### How to Use Parkos:

1. Visit the official website: parkos.es
2. Enter the airport name and your parking dates to view options.
3. Compare the prices and services of different parking lots to select the most suitable one.
4. Pay online and receive your parking confirmation.

**Target Users**: Travelers who need long-term parking near the airport.


![](/images/wechat/a2ab1bc043df.jpg)


## Summary

Whether it's for daily city parking or long-term airport parking in Spain, with the help of Telpark, EasyPark, and Parkos, you can easily solve your parking problems, saving both money and hassle.

item.description:
{
 "title": "Get a SIP Card (Health Card) and Vaccinations in Spain Without Social Security Contributions! A Personal Account",
 "body": "I recently went through the process myself at the community health center (Centre de Salut Lâ€™Eliana) in **Lâ€™Eliana**, in the Valencia region of Spain, and discovered that **even foreigners who do not pay into social security can get a free SIP card and receive the flu and COVID-19 mRNA vaccines!**

Today, I'm sharing the entire process in detail to help others who might need it.

---

### ğŸ’¡ What is a SIP card?

The SIP is the personal identification card for the Spanish healthcare system. Its full name is **â€œSistema de InformaciÃ³n Poblacionalâ€**.

With this card, you can:

* Visit public hospitals or community health centers;
* Receive various vaccines provided by the state (including flu, COVID-19, etc.);
* Get discounts on prescription medications;
* Keep a record of your vaccinations and medical history.


![](/images/wechat/925f956c0bae.jpg)


---

### ğŸªª 1. What kind of SIP card can you get without social security contributions?

For foreigners who are not working and do not contribute to social security (such as those with non-lucrative visas, students, or accompanying parents), you can apply for a temporary SIP card **\"without healthcare coverage (sin cobertura sanitaria)\"**.

This type of SIP card will be marked with \"**PRIVAD**,\" which means you are temporarily not entitled to national health insurance reimbursement, but it **can be used for vaccinations and emergency medical services**.

ğŸ“My card is printed with:

> *Sin cobertura sanitaria â€“ PÃºblica gratuita vacunaciÃ³n y urgencias*
> (Without healthcare coverage, free vaccination and emergency services)

This type of SIP card is **permanently valid**; as long as your information doesn't change, you don't need to renew it annually.

---

### ğŸ“ 2. Where to apply?

Go directly to the **Centro de Salud (community health center)** that corresponds to your residential area.

For example, in my town:

> **Centre de Salut Lâ€™Eliana**
> Address: Av. del Parc, 3
> Office Hours: Monday to Friday 8:00â€“20:00
> (SIP Application Hours: Monday to Friday 9:45â€“13:30)

The red sign at the entrance clearly statesğŸ‘‡

> *Conselleria de Sanitat Universal i Salut PÃºblica*
> *Generalitat Valenciana*

---


![](/images/wechat/f921d4260064.png)


### ğŸ§¾ 3. Required Documents

The staff only asked for the following three items:

1. âœ… Passport or NIE (residence card)
2. âœ… Proof of address (empadronamiento, also known as padron)
3. âœ… Phone number, email address

No social security contributions or private health insurance are required.

As long as you are a resident in the area, you can register and receive a SIP number.

---

### ğŸª™ 4. Application Process

1ï¸âƒ£ Go to the health center's front desk and say:

> â€œHola, quiero solicitar una tarjeta SIP.â€
> (Hello, I would like to apply for a SIP card.)

2ï¸âƒ£ The staff will verify your ID and address information.

3ï¸âƒ£ After a few minutes, they will print out a temporary, paper SIP card on the spot (white with red text).

4ï¸âƒ£ If you have a residence card or long-term residency proof, you can apply for a formal plastic card.

The whole process was very fast; I got mine in about 10 minutes.


![](/images/wechat/5e2b7583d416.png)


---

### ğŸ’‰ 5. Vaccination Process (Flu + COVID-19)

The Valencia region holds a unified **\"Flu + COVID-19 Vaccination Campaign\"** starting in mid-October each year.

This year's (2025) poster says:

> ğŸ—“ **Dates: October 16 to November 30**
> ğŸ•’ Monday, Thursday, Friday 10:00â€“13:00
> ğŸ•“ Specific dates in the afternoon 15:00â€“18:00
> ğŸ“ Location: Centre de FormaciÃ³n de Personas Adultas, Lâ€™Eliana (Av. del Parque, 3)

The key point isâ€”

> **No requiere cita previa (No appointment required)**
> Just bring your **SIP card**!

The atmosphere on-site is very relaxed, and volunteers and nurses will help you register and get vaccinated.

One shot for the flu, one for COVID-19, all done in a few minutes.

The elderly, patients with chronic diseases, children, and foreign residents can all get vaccinated for free.

---

### ğŸ§â€â™€ï¸ 6. On-site Experience

The vaccination site was set up at the Municipal Adult Education Center. The line wasn't long, about a 20-minute wait, mostly with elderly people.

The nurses were very skilled.


![](/images/wechat/76a33f55aea8.png)


ğŸ’¬ A nurse on-site specifically emphasized:

> â€œAs long as you have a SIP card, you can get vaccinated, regardless of whether you contribute to social security.â€

---

### ğŸ’¬ 7. Frequently Asked Questions (Q&A)

**Q1: My SIP card says â€œPRIVAD.â€ Can I get vaccinated?**
âœ… Yes! This type of card specifically allows for free vaccinations.

**Q2: Does the temporary SIP card have an expiration date?**
â³ There is no fixed expiration date. It remains valid as long as your information does not change.

**Q3: Can I apply without a padron (proof of address)?**
âŒ No. The padron is the only document that proves you live in the area, so it is mandatory. If you have a personal digital certificate, you can apply for and print it for free directly from the city hall's website where you are registered, saving you a trip. For minors, parents can use their digital certificate to apply on their behalf under the collective residence certificate section on the city hall's website. Approval takes about 1-3 business days, after which you can download the PDF certificate, all for free.

**Q4: Can I bring my child to get vaccinated?**
ğŸ‘§ Yes, children can also get their own SIP card. You just need to bring their NIE and padron (proof of address); the child does not need to be present.

---

### â¤ï¸ 8. Summary

In Spain, even if you don't have a job and don't pay into social security, as long as you are a resident, you can access **basic public health services**.

So don't hesitateâ€”grab your passport and proof of address, and head to your nearest health center to get a SIP card!

Not only can you get vaccinated, but it also creates a convenient record for future medical care.

---

ğŸ“Œ **Practical Information Summary:**

| Item | Information |
| --- | --- |
| Application Location | Centre de Salut (community health center) |
| Required Documents | Passport/NIE + padron (proof of address) |
| Social Security Required | âŒ No |
| Appointment Required | âŒ No |
| Available Vaccines | Flu / COVID-19 / Childhood vaccines, etc. |
| Cost | Free |
| Eligible Population | All residents in Spain (including foreigners) |

---"
}
